awd_titl_txt: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2020
awd_abstract_narration:
This action funds an NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology for FY 2020, Research Using Biological Collections. The fellowship supports research and training of the Fellow that will utilize biological collections in innovative ways. In fishes, different swimming movements and body shapes (morphologies) likely confer various functional advantages. A major example is the difference between steady and unsteady swimming specialists. Steady specialists, like trout, have streamlined forms that appear to minimize unfavorable forces and are found in areas of open water and high environmental flows. In contrast, unsteady-swimming specialists, like pike or bluegill, have bulkier bodies and fins that appear to maximize forces for short bursts of movement and for rapid turning in low-flow environments with lots of structure (vegetation, etc.). Previous studies indicate that the swimming abilities of unsteady specialists are more negatively affected by environmental flows than those of steady specialists, so it is thought that fish body shape and swimming ability influence fish habitat selection. But, the links between fish form, swimming, and habitat have rarely been formally tested. Temperate lake shorelines provide an excellent system in which to explore these relationships because they harbor a wide variety of fish species and habitats. Shorelines, globally, are one of the most threatened natural systems. So, in addition to providing a fundamental understanding of fish form and function, the Fellow’s findings will help predict how human-driven shoreline change influences fishes, inform lakes conservation programs, and provide habitat guidelines for shoreside construction and restoration. This work will also inform engineering applications by offering solutions for underwater vehicle design challenges.

The Fellow will use an interdisciplinary approach to both evaluate the strength of morphology-habitat associations and describe the physical mechanics that underly them, with the following three objectives. (1) Identify the axes of variation of morphology in Michigan inland lake fishes through measurements of museum specimens. (2) Determine how morphological features map to shoreline habitats along a turbulence gradient using ecological models based on specimen and lake survey data. (3) Evaluate the significance of morphology for tolerating environmental flows through hydrodynamic studies of live fishes swimming in flumes. Alongside the Fellow’s training in collections-based functional morphological and ecological modeling methods, the Fellow will recruit and train diverse undergraduate students through independent projects aligned with the Fellow’s work. Synergistic activities will include writing popular press articles, developing lessons for K-12 STEM classrooms, and hosting inquiry-based activities at natural history museums.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award supported a postdoctoral fellow’s research and training between Aug 1, 2020 and Aug 31, 2021 as part of the NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship in Biology (PRFB) program in Research Using Biological Collections. The award was terminated early at the fellow’s request because the fellow began a full-time professorship (13 out of 24 months completed).

Under this award, the fellow explored form-function relationships across Michigan inland lakes. To survive and reproduce, fishes must overcome challenges that arise from water’s physical properties. For example, in air, at the speeds most animals achieve, drag forces opposing locomotion are minimal, but water’s density means that drag forces can substantially impede locomotion. So, we might expect fishes’ body plans and movement patterns during swimming to reflect the challenges of generating forces to move through the water. In fact, different swimming movements and body shapes (morphologies) likely confer various functional advantages that aid in swimming in different environments. A major example is the difference between steady and unsteady swimming specialists. Steady specialists, like trout, have streamlined forms that appear to minimize unfavorable forces and are found in areas of open water and high environmental flows. In contrast, unsteady-swimming specialists, like pike or bluegill, have bulkier bodies and fins that appear to maximize forces for short bursts of movement and for rapid turning in low-flow environments with lots of structure (vegetation, etc.). While long hypothesized, these swimming specializations have rarely been tested.

Temperate lake shorelines were used as a model system because they harbor a wide variety of fish species and habitats.  Further, shorelines, globally, are one of the most threatened natural systems. So, in addition to providing a fundamental understanding of fish form and function, the fellow’s findings can help predict how human-driven shoreline change influences fishes, inform lakes conservation programs, and provide habitat guidelines for shoreside construction and restoration. This work can also inform engineering applications by offering solutions for underwater vehicle design challenges.

The fellow’s project was designed with two objectives: (1) evaluate the strength of morphology-habitat associations in Michigan inland lake fishes using morphology data derived from museum specimens and habitat and fish abundance data from surveys conducted by the Michigan Department of Natural Resources (MI-DNR), and (2) describe for the first time the physical mechanics that underly these relationships through studies of the forces produced along the bodies of live fishes swimming freely in flow tunnels.  COVID-19 safety measures limited access to research facilities, which greatly restricted the fellow’s work. So, Objective 1 was partially met, and Objective 2 was dropped. At the time of termination, the fellow had finished collecting morphology data from museum specimens, formed an ongoing partnership with MI-DNR, and begun exploring the lake survey data habitat characteristics that influence fish abundances. The completed research activities will serve as a launching point for the fellow’s future research program.

Specific training outcomes during the fellow’s tenure include the following: training in (1) research methods new to the fellow, such as specimen-based morphological data collection and ecological modeling, (2) developing partnerships with government agencies and stakeholders, (3) online teaching through guest lectures hosted on Zoom, (4) professional networking with remote colleagues through attendance at virtual conferences and hosting virtual coffee hours, and (5) mentorship through working with an undergraduate student to develop research protocols.

The fellow’s broader impact activities included outreach to several types of audiences: (1) researchers through a guest lecture for a biomechanics reading group hosted by researchers at the University of Calgary (participants included scholars from Canada, the US, the UK, and the Netherlands), (2) Masters and upper-level undergraduates as a guest lecturer on fish form and function in environmental science classes, (3) high school students as an expert panelist during the opening ceremonies of the National Ocean Sciences Bowl-Great Lakes Division’s 2021 regional competition, (4) elementary students by partnering with a school teacher as expert consultant to develop science lesson plans themed around the Great Lakes, and (5) the public by scripting and filming an educational video for the Harvard Museum of Natural History’s YouTube channel.
